sections.title: The Wisdom of Silence and Speech
The Dangers of Boasting and Deceit

verses.text: There is a rebuke that is untimely, and there is a person who stays silent and is considered wise.
verses.comment: This verse sets the stage for a meditation on the wisdom of speech and silence. Sometimes, remaining silent avoids greater harm and can reveal prudence, a trait highly valued in biblical wisdom literature.
verses.sectionHeader: The Wisdom of Silence and Speech

verses.text: How much better it is to rebuke than to harbor anger, and the one who pleads his case will be kept from injury.
verses.comment: Sirach highlights the virtue of open rebuke over silent resentment, recalling the wisdom tradition that values corrective speech (cf. Proverbs 27:5), suggesting that addressing wrongs directly prevents greater harm.

verses.text: And the one who admits his fault will be kept from failure.
verses.comment: Admitting one's fault is shown as a safeguard against greater ruin, echoing the biblical theme of humility and repentance leading to restoration (cf. Psalm 32:5).

verses.text: Like a eunuch lusting to violate a girl is the person who does right under compulsion.
verses.comment: Acting rightly only under compulsion, like a eunuch's fruitless desire, renders virtue empty—a warning against mere external compliance without sincere intent (cf. Isaiah 29:13).

verses.text: Some keep silent, because they have nothing to say; others keep silent, because they know the right time.
verses.comment: This verse distinguishes between emptiness and discernment. Discerning when to speak is a mature virtue – as seen in Christ's trial (cf. Matt. 26:63), where silence itself became testimony.

verses.text: A wise man will be silent until the right moment, but a braggart and fool ignores opportunity.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not merely in having knowledge, but knowing when it is wise to share it. This echoes the importance of prudence and self-control in spiritual life.

verses.text: Whoever talks too much will be detested, and whoever pretends to authority will be hated.
verses.comment: This reflects the biblical warning against pride and empty talk. False claims to authority are especially condemned—reminding us that true authority comes by humble service, as modeled by Christ (cf. Phil. 2:8-9).

verses.text: There may be good fortune in disaster, and there may be gain in adversity.
verses.comment: God can bring good out of suffering. This anticipates the cross, where Christ transformed the greatest evil into the greatest good for humanity—demonstrating God’s providence even in hardship.

verses.text: There is a gift that profits only by loss, and there is a gift whose return is double.
verses.comment: True generosity multiplies, while gifts given grudgingly or with wrong motives may harm the giver. The spiritual principle of charity—giving freely—brings blessing.

verses.text: There is humiliation because of glory, and there is one who lifts his head after being humbled.
verses.comment: Humiliation can lead to greater honor in the end. This prefigures Christ’s pattern: humiliation before exaltation. God exalts the humble.

verses.text: Some buy much for little, but pay seven times its worth.
verses.comment: This proverbial insight warns against shortsightedness. Earthly bargains can have hidden costs; only prudent stewardship, guided by virtue, is truly profitable.

verses.text: The wise make themselves beloved by their words, but the courtesies of fools are wasted.
verses.comment: Gracious words have power to build up, in contrast with empty flattery: a central theme in the teaching of Jesus and the entire wisdom tradition.

verses.text: A fool’s gift will not profit you, because his look is begrudging and he gives with reproach; he opens his mouth like a town crier, but the gift is begrudged.
verses.comment: The intention behind generosity matters. God values the heart’s disposition in giving—foreshadowing Christ's teaching that almsgiving, prayer, and fasting should be done in secret and without hypocrisy (cf. Matt. 6:1-4).

verses.text: Today he lends and tomorrow demands it back; such a man will be hated.
verses.comment: Self-interested giving breeds resentment. True charity is not transactional. This prepares the heart for Gospel charity, where love seeks nothing in return.

verses.text: A fool says, 'I have no friends, and no thanks for the good I have done; those who eat my bread speak evil of me.'
verses.comment: Complaints about ungrateful friends foreshadow Judas’ betrayal of Jesus. The Psalm quoted by Jesus at the Last Supper develops this theme of suffering at the hands of close companions.

verses.text: How many will laugh at him, and how often!
verses.comment: Derision befalls those with foolish or insincere motives. This points toward the suffering Messiah mocked by the crowds, a suffering that becomes redemptive (cf. Isaiah 53:3).

verses.text: Better is a slip on the ground than a slip of the tongue. Thus the downfall of the evil will come swiftly.
verses.comment: Speech can harm more than physical accidents. This is why Scripture warns so strongly about taming the tongue.

verses.text: A slip on the pavement is better than a slip of the tongue; the downfall of the wicked will occur just as speedily.
verses.comment: Speech can cause deeper injury than physical missteps, resonating with wisdom teachings on the power of words (cf. James 3:6); both warn of swift consequences for heedlessness.

verses.text: A proverb from a fool's mouth will be rejected, because he does not speak it at the proper time.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not in the words themselves, but in knowing how and when to employ them. Timing and disposition matter—a major theme for the wise.

verses.text: One may be prevented from sinning by want, so when he rests he will not be burdened with remorse.
verses.comment: A lack of opportunity, rather than intent, can sometimes keep people from sin. This highlights the importance of purification of the heart, not just of external actions.

verses.text: Some lose everything out of shame, and gain nothing out of it, but there are those who lose themselves for the sake of it and end up gaining double.
verses.comment: This paradox echoes Jesus’ teaching that whoever loses his life for His sake will save it. Divine reward often comes hidden under an apparent loss.

verses.text: A fool out of shame gives promises to a friend, but ends up turning him into an enemy needlessly.
verses.comment: Promises made from embarrassment or peer pressure can backfire. Wise speech, thoughtfully considered, preserves true friendship.

verses.text: A lie is a wicked blot in a man; it will always dwell in the mouth of the ignorant.
verses.comment: Lies defile a person and reveal spiritual ignorance. Jesus called the devil the father of lies, highlighting a direct division between truth and evil.

verses.text: A thief is better than a habitual liar, but both will inherit destruction.
verses.comment: The comparison shocks: in some ways, open theft is less corrupt than a lying life, but both are condemned. All mortal sins destroy grace and fellowship with God unless repented.

verses.text: The disposition of a liar leads to dishonor, for his shame will never be wiped out.
verses.comment: Repetitive lying destroys personal character and social trust. Integrity must be maintained consistently, a truth affirmed throughout the wisdom tradition.

verses.text: A liar’s way leads to disgrace, and his shame is ever with him.
verses.comment: Persistent lying leads to social disgrace and lasting shame, reaffirming the ethical centrality of truthfulness in both wisdom literature (Proverbs 19:5) and the prophetic tradition.

verses.text: The wise person advances himself by his words, and one who is sensible pleases the great.
verses.comment: Wise speech leads to personal advancement and wins the favor of those in authority, demonstrating the practical social benefits of prudence (cf. Proverbs 16:23).
verses.sectionHeader: The Dangers of Boasting and Deceit

verses.text: Those who cultivate the soil heap up their harvest, and those who please the great atone for injustice.
verses.comment: Just as diligent farmers reap abundant harvests, those who wisely please those in power can rectify injustices—highlighting the value of social harmony and responsible influence.

verses.text: Favors and gifts blind the eyes of the wise; like a muzzle on the mouth they stop reproofs.
verses.comment: Sirach warns that even those renowned for wisdom can be compromised by gifts or bribery, a common concern in ancient societies, leading them to overlook wrongdoing; this theme echoes Deuteronomy 16:19, emphasizing justice’s vulnerability to corruption.

verses.text: Better is the person who hides his folly than the one who hides his wisdom.
verses.comment: It is more virtuous to keep one’s faults concealed through repentance than to conceal wisdom that could benefit others. The biblical tradition always values the diffusion of truth.

verses.text: Better are those who hide their folly than those who hide their wisdom.
verses.comment: Concealing folly is deemed wiser than hiding one's wisdom, emphasizing the persistent biblical preference for humility over pretension (cf. Proverbs 12:23).
